title: R42741
content: The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents, with over $40 billion in annual benefits. Participation is voluntary, with 85% of employees and 90% of retirees enrolled. Coverage options include individual, family, and self plus one plans in fee-for-service or health maintenance organizations. Premiums are shared between the federal. The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents through fee-for-service (FFS) or health maintenance organizations (HMOs). Premiums are shared between the federal government and the employee or retiree. Benefits and cost sharing vary among FEHB plans, covering basic services like hospital and physician care with deductibles, co-payments, or coinsurance. Prior to FEHB's creation in 1959, federal employees obtained health insurance independently or through union plans. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established parameters for eligibility, coverage election, types of health plans, and government's share of premiums for federal employees. It also created an Employees Health Benefits Fund and outlined the role of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) in managing the program. FEHBA established the role of OPM in managing the program and the government's authority to contract with insurers. The general model of FEHB, with enrollees choosing coverage from private insurers, has remained consistent. Changes have been made to the government's share of premiums and eligibility, services, and benefits have been expanded over time through legislative modifications by Congress. Since its inception, the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program has seen an increase in eligibility, services, and benefits. Congress plays a role in modifying the program, either proposing changes or reacting to them. The FEHB model involves competing insurers offering various coverage options to enrollees with minimal intervention from OPM. This model is considered successful in allowing enrollees to make cost-conscious choices and controlling overall program costs. Researchers have explored the possibility of applying aspects of the FEHB model to other healthcare programs like Medicare. Researchers have considered exporting aspects of the successful FEHB model to other healthcare programs, such as Medicare, and expanding access to provide coverage to non-federal workers. Some policymakers have introduced legislation to create new programs or expand FEHB eligibility. Lessons from FEHB have been seen as instructive for establishing health insurance exchanges under the ACA. Congressional interest in FEHB extends beyond its potential applicability as a model for other healthcare programs. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) has sparked Congressional interest in the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program, which Congress has a financial interest in and legislative authority to restructure. This report aims to explain the evolution of FEHB and how Congress has interacted with the program, including conditioning the use of federal funds on policy changes. Congress has conditioned the use of federal funds on policy changes in the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program. Changes include modifying the formula for determining the government's share of FEHB premiums, eligibility criteria, and policies affecting the relationship between Medicare and FEHB. Additionally, Congress passed laws prohibiting the use of federal funds for abortions, except in cases where the woman's life is in danger. The provision prohibiting the use of federal funds for abortions was renewed annually with few changes, except in 1994 and 1995 when it was excluded. The government's share of FEHB premiums has increased over the years, with the formula for determining the share changing in 1971 to the "big six" formula. The "big six" formula for setting the government's share of FEHB premiums was introduced in 1971, with the government contributing 72% of the weighted average premium of all plans. This formula replaced the original 40% share and was in effect until 1997 when it was updated by the Balanced Budget Act. Eligible participants included federal employees, retirees, and their family members. Since its enactment, eligibility for the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program has been extended to various categories of federal employees, retirees, and their family members. In 1978, part-time employees were included, and in 1988, certain temporary workers became eligible. Temporary continuation of coverage (TCC) was also authorized in 1988, allowing separated employees to continue FEHB coverage for up to 18 months by paying the full premium. The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program has expanded eligibility over the years to include part-time employees, retirees, and certain temporary workers. Temporary continuation of coverage (TCC) allows separated employees to maintain FEHB coverage for up to 18 months by paying the full premium, including the government's and employees' shares, and a 2% administrative fee. Children aging out of their parents' plans may qualify for 36 months of coverage. In 1982, Congress passed the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act, enabling federal workers to be eligible for Medicare based on their federal employment. The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program was established by the Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (P.L. 86-382) on September 28, 1959. It set the parameters for eligibility, enrollment procedures, benefits, premium shares, and the role of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) for federal employees and retirees. Eligible participants included current federal employees and retirees who retired after July 1, 1960, with at least 12 years of service or for a disability. The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program, established in 1959, required retirees to have at least 12 years of service or retire due to disability. Participants had to be enrolled in an FEHB plan for at least five years prior to retirement. OPM could contract or approve different types of health benefit plans for FEHB participation. Employee Organization Plans provide health benefits to members of the organization sponsored by employee organizations. Comprehensive Medical Plans include group-practice prepayment plans and individual-practice prepayment plans. The government's share was 50% of the lowest carrier rate for service and indemnity plans. Biweekly government shares ranged from $1.25 to $4.25 for individual and family coverage, with different rates for female employees with family coverage. For employee organization and comprehensive medical plans, the government's share was 50% of the biweekly premium, capped at $2.50 for individual coverage and $6.00 for family coverage.
